Over 1k Hours played. This game is certainly relaxing if your just looking to chill and farm. The Deep Desert is a mixed experience though. At first, we had to creep around at 3:00 AM because literally 1 guild locked down every shipwreck and facility worth doing. It was not fun fighting outnumbered against players who were literally gatekeeping the best schematics. Even if you did manage to sneak some, you never had enough resources to build past 2 items-that same guild locked down both the large resource islands. Now, many months later, with the changes to the DD, and that guild long gone, I have been able to finally stockpile a massive amount of resources and schematics on my own. I do not really think the resource denial and gatekeeping creates any end game. Keeping gear out of players hands and limiting to a few elite players who are only here so as long that status quo stays just creates a negative play experience for most of the population.

I enjoy pvp, but not when I am risking my equipment that was extremely difficult for me to get. Dying 4 or 5 times literally puts your equipment at 60% durability. There is not any gain to just fighting losing battles, as your the one taking the durability loss. So you create situations that guarantee victory, which creates more negative play experience for the ones losing. You literally get nothing for fighting other people, other than just the fight. Sure, you can loot them, but their loot is not anything you can't get on your own. There is no specific PvP resource anyone drops. no tokens to be exchanged at a pvp vendor for rare cosmetics or skins. There is not even a PvP objective to fight over in the DD.  FFA PvP is just filler content, you can't create a PvP endgame with only FFA PvP, with nothing to fight over. If fighting over denying resources and progression is intended, than that is a model that is terrible for the health of a game.

I really enjoy this game, but I had to experience the worst form of it, and all while undergeared fighting uphill battles, while outnumbered, against superior geared groups. That is kind of a trash experience, that most players will not ride out. Now, that it is easier to get what you need to progress out in the DD, the game is fine.  I want to see big guild vs guild battles, but you need to give these people something that matters to fight over, not just randomly steamrolling solos to pass the time, or gatekeeping progression. Until there is actually an endgame, Dune Awakening remains a chill resourcing game that lets you chill out, and sometimes fight in the DD, if your server is more friendly.

[h1] A promising foundation with incredible potential [/h1]

I really enjoy the worldbuilding aspect of Dune: Awakening. The atmosphere, sound design, and sense of scale capture Arrakis beautifully. This game has a lot of potential, and I truly hope the developers continue expanding it with new content and story updates in the coming years.

I mainly play for PvE, and it would be great to see more vehicles, technologies, and unique building pieces as progression rewards. Another feature that would greatly enhance both solo and group play is an arsenal or gear loadout system. Being able to save and quickly switch between different builds, such as skills, weapons, and armor, would streamline gameplay and make experimentation much more enjoyable. It would help players adapt to different challenges without constantly reorganizing their inventories, and it would support more meaningful buildcrafting in the long term. In the far future, it would be amazing if we could eventually construct our own spacecraft and travel off-world to explore planets mentioned in the Dune universe. There’s so much rich lore to draw from, and I hope one day the game can take us beyond Arrakis.

For PvP, I think dedicated game modes could add variety beyond the Deep Desert sandbox. A team-based duel arena or a free-for-all (FFA) mode for competitive players, a large-scale “Big Team Battle” (BTB)” mode with vehicles and objective-based matches, or even vehicle racing across dunes and canyons could create exciting and focused experiences. It would also be great to have ranked matchmaking and proper scoreboards, so players can track performance, progression, and improvement over time. Bringing your character build into these modes would allow players to test themselves in a more structured and competitive environment. A loadout system would also support these PvP modes by allowing players to quickly switch between specialized builds before matches. Match rewards or cosmetic emblems could further enhance long-term progression. There are many exciting possibilities for additional game modes.

There are many community discussions about the game’s current state and its future, and I hope the developers continue listening and adjusting direction where needed. I understand that game development is complex and full of technical challenges, so I genuinely appreciate the consistent patches and the addition of community-requested features week after week. Progress is gradual, but it is clear that the game is improving, even though there is still a lot of work ahead.

One suggestion I’d like to offer is improving communication. While updates through social media and Discord are helpful, it would be fantastic to see monthly developer talks or livestreams, similar to what Digital Extremes does with Warframe. More open and transparent communication would help players feel involved and informed, and give us a clearer sense of the game’s direction. Even if it’s too early for full dev streams, beginning this kind of conversation would greatly strengthen trust between the developers and the community.

Dune is a very special IP, and Dune: Awakening already shows respect for its legacy. I’m excited to see where the game goes, and I hope the team continues building on this strong foundation to deliver the best version of this ambitious vision.

I never write reviews, but Dune: Awakening absolutely deserves one. This is the first game I’ve played that feels like it gets everything right! Based on initial impressions.

Immersion & Visuals
The graphics are breathtaking — Arrakis comes alive with stunning landscapes and an atmosphere that pulls you in completely. Every detail, from the shifting sands to the looming threat of the sandworms (Shai-Hulud), makes the world feel both beautiful and dangerous.

Storytelling & Progression
The narratives are rich and varied, weaving together lore in a way that feels authentic to the Dune universe. Despite the game’s depth, it never overwhelms. Instead, it guides you in the beginning step by step, making the learning curve smooth and rewarding. Dune: Awakening has solo gameplay, dungeons and raids both co-op and player-vs-player zones.

Gameplay & Systems
It captures the essence of an MMO with survival mechanics, researching, crafting, roleplaying, guilds, customization, skill trees and armor skins — all seamlessly integrated. Combat is intuitive, fun, and competitive, whether you’re teaming up in co-op or testing your skills in player-vs-player. Even with so many features, the menus remain clean, clear, and easy to navigate, which is a rare achievement. If you have the computer/system for it you get deep shadows, rich colouring, best anti-aliasing, great field of depth, view distance as far as the eye can reach, beautiful effects and post-processing. On top of that there is DLSS frame generation for smooth gameplay without the frame generation caveats you see in other games.

Future Potential
Currently, the adventure is set on Arrakis, but the lore (also in the books) hints at other planets like Caladan, Kaitain, and Giedi Prime etc. The thought of exploring these planets in future updates is thrilling — the possibilities truly feel endless!

Community & Accessibility
Concerns about server populations are addressed with planned server merges, ensuring a vibrant player base. Best of all, there’s no battle pass pressuring you to log in daily; you can enjoy the game at your own pace without fear of missing out.

Concerns
Yes, will there be enough endgame content? However, I read that Funcom is addressing this. Actively thinking about improvements, keeping it fresh and challenging.

Dune: Awakening isn’t just another survival RPG — it’s a living, breathing universe that respects its players and its source material. If this is only the beginning, the future of the game looks extraordinary. It's a must play!

First of all - if you’re a fan of Dune - book, movie or both - you’d most likely enjoy this game, unless there is strong aversion to gaming in general and light survival games in particular. In my opinion spirit of this universe was represented almost immaculately.

Now as for various aspects of the game for those who are not fans yet - it’s quite decent game, not Game of The Year material, but definitely not a tie-in trash as many other games made during hype of many, many intellectual properties.

Audio would be easiest to dissect - it’s not Hans Zimmer level, but fits into the atmosphere well, audio tracks don’t awaken an urge to turn them off and sound design is done well, without noticeable issues.

Graphically speaking it’s a good looking game, considering that there was not much freedom in terms of colour and design depiction of Arrakis - desert planet, job was nicely done. World is not ugly and for the most part was made to not be that monotonous. Vehicles, people, weapons and ofc the Maker himself - Shai Hulud are mostly nailed and very impressive to see. In particular worms - giant forever threats are as majestic and dangerous as they should be, seeing humongous one swallowing big spice field is something else. Almost forgot about sandstorms - those are mostly less dangerous compared to worm, but a sight to behold too.
But.. nothing is ideal - there are things that could have been done a lot better - some designs are not impressive to say the least and developers slack off on adding new ones or increasing amount of already existing, since game is still in its first year of life after release there should be more stuff introduced variety-wise, but as recent dlc showed, they want to limit it to lowest possible minimum, only giving more after huge public outcry.
And then there are bugs and glitches that you’d encounter a bit too often for my taste, graphical ones are mostly not dangerous, but few of them might kill you unfortunately and death in survival game is never easy to get over.

Plot premise is given in intro cinematic so it’s not a spoiler - you are in one of endless possibilities seen by Muad’Dib, world where Lady Jessica did not go against her orders and gave birth to a girl, so there was no Paul Atreides, Harkonnen were not able to destroy Duke Leto and take over Dune, Sardaukar killed Fremen so general situation is still kinda cold warish. You could pick one of two sides - Harkonnen or Atreides, but don’t expect it to be like Horde and Alliance - there is very little impact on game depending on your choice - it’s pretty much just few quests and pricing of respective house flair. There are several main storylines, none of which are yet finished due to new episodes coming along game life cycle, before DLC there were only 2 parts out with a number of side stories, more are expected to come later too.

Gameplay-wise it’s multiplayer survival game that’s pvevp, most things could be kept strictly pve, but for some things, you;d have to venture into pvp areas. Before late game that should not be that big of an issue - pvp places would mostly be without conflict, thought it’d probably depend on particular server you play on. It’s a lot better to play with somebody, and a bunch of endgame things are pretty much impossible without friends or guild. 
Survival stuff is mostly down to few dangers - thirst, cause it’s desert planet, duh. Sunstrike - same reason. Worms - extreme game of floor is lava, where lava is all the sand on this sand planet, also you lose everything on you or if he also ate vehicle - in your vehicle if worm gets you. Death of other causes lets you recover your corpse. Sand storms could be quite a pain if one is not careful, but are way easier to deal with compared to worm. And radiation that’s limited to few areas but would be very deadly without proper protection. Other stuff might increase your chance of dying, but will not kill you directly - like drum sand or quicksand.
Besides that - game is third person adventure with light rpg elements. You’d be gathering resources, build bases, killing npcs and clearing enemy strongholds. Ofc since it’s Dune we are talking about spice is also among necessities and getting it is wrought with dangers and every endgame thing requires spice and not a small amount of it. So friend and guilds are essential to do big spice runs with harvesters, carriers and guard ornithopters.
But here lies biggest vice i have with the game atm - game breaking bugs that could push you way back in progress. Simplest one - dcs, you could be booted out of the game at any moment, but most of ones encountered were during zone change in deep desert or between deep desert and hagga basin, considering that if you leave game outside of safe zone, your character stays in game for several minutes, there is quite a good chance you might log in to corpse. Vehicle remains where you leave it unless destroyed too. Next on the list - everything is a rock - bug that could randomly happen anytime where you lose ability to interact with anything - your vehicle or base - nothing would appear functional, it’s also bug my first ornithopter loss was caused by, I had to way to get away from worm in the middle of sand plain. Getting same issue while at base it inconvenient, but shutting game completely and running it again should resolve it. Another great bug - being unable to move - only your movement abilities work - like dash or hook, walking, jumping or running is inaccessible - bug that took my most recent ornithopter full of spice and my gear. Getting stuck in textures also happen, which would make you easy worm meal if it happens in the open too - my second flyer was done in by that one. There are other less horrific ones that are quite specific and could be avoided if you’re lucky even when struck by them - like worm spawning directly under your spice gathering place that leaves you with smth like one second to get away from it or textures that failed to load and might cause you to fall through the world.

So there you have it - game is pretty good and I quite enjoyed it as evident from number of hours spent, but some bugs might throw you into despair after losing so much progress, that’d require sometimes tens of hours to recover.

P.S. if you ever build base, you’d have to log in to keep it up, without paying taxes and refueling generators, power goes out, shield protecting base goes down and sand storms wipe everything in a bit.

Dune: Awakening manages to do what so many other survival games fail to do: genuinely surprise the player with fresh mechanics.

I am a long-time player of survival games, and I was getting tired of the same repetitive loop: chop wood, mine stone, build a square base, repeat. Dune breaks free from this mold. The core ideas here—the combination of social conflict, exploration on Arrakis, the terrifying Sandworm threat, and the unique mobility tools (like the Suspensor Belt, which is awesome even if it breaks quickly!)—are all concepts I’ve been searching for in this genre for years.

The game is not just a coat of Dune paint on an old survival template; it introduces elements that make you rethink how you approach every moment:

The environment itself (the deep desert) is a constantly looming threat.

The progression systems feel well-designed and rewarding.

The blend of sci-fi building with survival strategy is executed brilliantly.

⚠️ A Word of Warning (The Grind):
Yes, be warned: the game is extremely grind-heavy right now. Resources are constantly needed, and the crafting process can feel slow, which is definitely a point the developers need to address.

HOWEVER: For me, this is a minor trade-off. The unique elements and the feeling of actual, consequential danger on Arrakis make the repetitive crafting and resource gathering feel meaningful—it’s worth the effort to unlock the next piece of unique tech.

Final Thoughts:
If you are a survival veteran tired of the same old formula and crave truly fresh ideas and mechanics—not just a new skin—Dune: Awakening is a must-buy. Dive in and feel the risk of walking on the sand again.

At 423 hours played as of this review, I can say that I still enjoy the game, but I don't play nearly as often as the initial weeks of 'every possible waking hour'.  With that said, I didn't rush to end game.  I took my time, explored, progressed through the story carefully and deliberately.  I have completed every quest I can find to complete up until the deep desert and have only briefly explored there - because I don't enjoy PvP (especially broken PvP). If you love Dune or survival games, you'll get many hours of entertainment from it if you're playing for the crafting/building/survival aspect or the story.  You will initially *feel* the relentless danger that is Arrakis, you will fight to survive.  I thoroughly enjoyed the beginnings of it, and I absolutely feel as though I've gotten my money's worth out of it.

End game is... problematic.  I don't like PvP, and I don't like that much of the highest tier is locked behind it.  There should be some alternate path for PvE (and now, solo) players.  However, I don't begrudge those who enjoy PvP and I want those people to have that option.

Also problematic is the auction house / player run economy.  It's in shambles, with a dearth of offerings, and of those appearing many are ridiculously overpriced.  Thankfully the proffered items aren't really necessary for play.

I say solo, above, because that's what it has become unfortunately.  I still maintain my base, as well as my guild base, and the base of a friend, all by myself.  It's been sad seeing all of the bases around mine crumbling to dust and I'm surprised (pleasantly) when I do run across someone else in the open world.  I miss those with whom I used to play.

Finally, the story.  I have enjoyed it, most especially the initial chapter / Fremen storyline.  While I don't really like part of the revealed backstory as the playthrough continued (no spoilers), I can live with it.  What has infuriated me, however, are certain actions taken that are forced, especially one event in particular that I was hoping would be rectified in the most recent chapter but was seemingly reinforced.  I am still hoping for an eventual reunion, but realize it may never come.

I *do* want more story though.  I want the next chapter.  For now, that is what will draw me back into the game.

10/10: Finally, A Survival Game That Captures the Soul-Crushing Dread of a Broken-Down Prius.

You are now stranded—10 clicks from the nearest safe zone, with a leviathan circling and nothing but your survival knife, a canteen of water, and the bitter taste of failure.

Forget the epic grandeur of the films. Dune: Awakenings doesn't want you to conquer Arrakis; it wants you to understand the existential despair of a 9-to-5 worker whose car broke down ten miles from the office.

The game's "beautiful, brutal difficulty" doesn't kick in with a massive sandworm fight or an intense spice raid. No. The New Goal: A Long Walk Home.

Your new mission isn't to build, or fly, or harvest—it's to survive the commute.

I am a hardcore gamer, I have comfortably averaged 30+ hours of this every week since launch... and I am still learning and finding new joy. But plenty will come and smash through a great story and campaign and shelve it for later and that's just fine. Play it how you want to, but don't yell for them to make a different game to what it is because you don't like it.

You'll often see bad reviews alongside more than a couple of hundred hours played - is that really a bad experience if you played that much? Most games target somewhere around 50-70 hours on a general 'play through' and this is very much the type of experience where you can go at your own pace.

Expect a formidable player vs player experience in the Deep Desert and enjoy the challenge. The game has a remarkable balance for ground combat considering the mechanics have barely been touched in the first 5 months since release. There's plenty of improvements to be found but that is in the pursuit of one of the all time great gaming experiences in my view. I'm itching for more and have absolute confidence that Dune Awakening will live a long and fulfilling life well beyond my own personal 2025 game of the year view.

Play Time: 475.3 hours
The theme of the game is fantastic.
The story is excellent.
However, turning something so beautiful into this mess is a real skill in ruining things; it’s the answer to how you can take something that started well and make it terrible.

As a working adult, my most valuable asset is time. If a game can take away everything you’ve worked on for months in a single mistake, you cannot hide behind the excuse of “This is a Survival game”.

What does this mean? You work, you get tired, then you log into the game to relax. With your already tired mind, you make a tiny mistake, and the game punishes you by taking away months of effort. No, no one has the right to punish a working player like this. I paid for the game; I didn’t pay to have all my work taken away because of a single mistake. My time is worth more than the $50 I spent on this game.

When the game first launched, the player count was very high, even requiring long waits to enter servers. But the disappointment was so quick that within a month, the game lost approximately 90% of its players.

Structural bugs, logical errors, in-game glitches, and exploits allowed some players to advance unfairly, causing this massive player loss.

The excuse the developers hide behind is: “This is an Open-World Survival RPC game.”
Yes, I love this genre. But taking away everything I built over months in a single mistake and calling it a “Survival game” is pure nonsense. I have been a gamer for 35 years, I am 52 years old, and I have played many games in this genre. None of them punished players this severely. No other game has ever wiped 475 hours and 4 months of work with one mistake.

The game’s actual type isn’t survival—it’s regain what you lost.

95% of players play games to progress, to improve, and to test themselves at the highest levels. They want to develop strategies and diversify their skills. In this game, however: do your best → make a mistake → lose everything → rebuild if you still have the strength.
Spend your hours, days, months; make one mistake, lose it all, start over. No, this is not survival; it’s punishing players because the developers cannot provide meaningful progression. This is for people who enjoy pain—if you are masochistic and enjoy self-inflicted challenges, this game is perfect for you.

But if you are a working adult, with limited free time, who comes home to enjoy the game, one small mistake wipes everything you’ve done, and you lose not just the game, but all your motivation and enthusiasm. And this is called “survival”? No, the developers misunderstand the concept entirely.

Players who are lost this way cannot even be partially recovered. After this failure, the next release will be met with skepticism from players. I have added all FUNCOM games to my blacklist, and I will recommend all my gamer friends to avoid them. I recommend the same to you: do not play, do not let others play, do not recommend, and do not be complicit in harming others.

Ultimately, if you compare the number of players motivated to rebuild what they lost versus those who will simply quit, the majority will not be willing to redo everything. This means the game targets not the general or majority audience, but a small group that enjoys suffering, is masochistic, and has an abundance of cheap time.

With the Steamawards i feel like it is time to write a review. This is not a bad game. I would say, at the time of this writing, it has about 100 to 150 hours worth of single player content. More, if you like base building or are a completionist.

So… why don’t I recommend the game?

I don’t recommend the game because it doesn’t feel very “Dune”. The premise of the game is an alternate reality. Paul never was born, his mother gave birth to a girl as she was supposed to. This results in her Jessica getting more training by the BG and in the end able to discover the plot against the Artreides. This resulting in a new “war on arrakis” and the eradication of the Fremen. Why? Who the F knows. Centuries nobody cared about the Fremen being around, suddenly the Imperator decides to eradicate them and with them the very thing why I am coming to play this game.

I didn’t come to ride around on a bike, drive a buggy, or float around the sky with my repulsor field. I came to wear a Stilsuit, survive the desert and go “native”. And… you can’t. The game virtually forces you to join a house and a guild. Sure, you can create a Guild of 1.. But you need to be in a guild to take part in the Landsraat and get its cosmetic and gear rewards. And the Guild you join needs to ally with either Artreides or Harkonnen. That is not what i came for. I didn’t come to play Dune to wear a heavy armor and run around with a shotgun, shooting at people ziplining through the air as if this was “Lawbreakers”. A game that failed for a reason.

The PvP in this game isn’t enjoyable and only compounded by the fact that the Talent Trees, despite having absolute freedom to build a build, has no variety. There are like one and a half viable builds. Maybe 4 abilities worth using in the end game.

But that isn’t an issue, because there is no end game. Everything you need to do Single Player you get in Hagga Basin. There is no need to go to the deep desert. You go to the deep desert to get the gear, tech and equipment to play PvP in the deep desert. But there is nothing permanent in the Deep Desert. Its an empty square in which spice fields spawn. Spice fields you only really need to get the gear to do PvP.

Problem with PvP? I mean aside of the lack of variety and the boring combat system… Each tier is about 25% stronger than the previous Tier and “Uniques”, which you grind for, are somewhere between 0,5 to ,75 to the next tier. So a Tier 6 armor and weapon is 25% better than a Tier 5 one. And a Tier 6 Unique is 15-20% stronger than a Tier 6 common. This means, if you do not have the best of the best, you can be certain to fight with a disadvantage.

So, while the early hours of the game absolutely gave me what I came for… Desert Survival…it gradually stripped away everything that felt like Dune and gradually turned it into Generic Syfy shooter with a Dune veneer. An a thin one at that.

The fact that the story isn’t done isn’t helpful either. I can’t even recommend the game as a single player, because you barely have the Prologue to play. Maybe in 2 years this game will be worth recommending and unfortunately I am aware that a recommendation, or lack there of, like this is very much a risk that this game never gets the rest of the story.

Maybe in 2 years we’ll actually get to go native. But for the moment? For the moment, it starts strong and then quickly turns into generic Syfy, where you ride around in your vehicle and the worm is more a tedious nuisance than atmospheric encounter.

As it stands, I can't recommend this game.

Let me get this out of the way to start with: The game is seriously flawed and I do not recommend it at this time under the marketing description. 

The pros: I enjoyed the hell out of this game--it's such a fantastic world to delve into. There is tremendous--and I mean TREMENDOUS potential here. I haven't experienced such awe since the first days of World of Warcraft. Base-building (as so many have pointed out) is amazing. The survival elements are fun. The combat is constantly tweaked, so sometimes it's amazing and... we'll leave that for the negatives. The vehicles are all interesting and (at different stages) all useful. There story is solid and interesting. There's a lurking mystery behind everything. Dune is such a rich world in which to develop a game.

The cons: end-game is lacking. That is a common complaint. Fixable. I hold out hope. Combat is tweaked without reflection (or perhaps without intent) such that, for example, melee combat has been nerfed into the dirt. This is a systemic failure. Along the same lines, patches are half-baked. A lot of good stuff is added with each major patch, but hot fixes are too common. That brings me to my main complaint: if you play at the wrong times of day, expect server shutdowns VERY frequently for hotfixes. I've found myself, lately, not being able to play the game because they are hotfixing every night, cutting 2-3 hours out of my available playtime. This is another systemic failure. Patches should be thoroughly tested for things like... resource nodes being totally screwed up. NPC combatants being vastly overpowered (relative to build) to the point where solo play in the late game is whittled down to a handful of very specific builds which are ever-changing because they're ever-screwing-up the balance in massive ways, etc.

There is a ton of potential here. A very good core game ruined by development SLOP. Get your **** together, Funcom. The recipe is there. JUST. FOLLOW. IT. You want money? You got it. JUST. DO. BETTER.

The long and short of it: This game needed another 2-3 years of dev time. You're paying full price to play an Early Access game. 

Hagga Basin. The main PVE zone you start in is pretty decent, albeit the points of interests are too copy/pasted.
The story quests are incomplete. They just end abruptly. 

The worms, while appropriate for the Lore, ultimately shrink Hagga Basin even smaller than it already is and forces everyone to build on hills, cliffs, pathways, and resource spawn points. 

The crafting tech tree is very basic. Not even half as fleshed out as Conan Exiles. You're basically crafting the same stuff from tier 1 to 6 but with higher stats.

The way the tech tree and resource gathering works makes 2/3 of Hagga Basin obsolete. Which tends to herd the player base to build in the same general areas, Making Arrakis look more like a city rather than a harsh desert. 

Much of the resource gathering requires engaging in combat. The combat in this game is simply terrible.

The Deep Desert. This game's alleged end game. It's pretty obvious they just duct tapped this into the game last minute. They did very little if any testing to make sure the systems worked as intended or if it was even fun to play. 

Its more of the same except now you're in an empty, featureless desert far bigger than it needs to be. So you end up flying around for 20 minutes hoping to find anything.

The real cherry on top is the DD was an entire pvp zone. So if you wanted to engage in "end game" content, you had to do it while under threat of being harassed by other players. A complete FFA zone. Including guild members and same faction players. They created the best ganking and griefing environment in any modern video game.

Unfair and frustrating PvP completely ruins what could have been a great game. Here is why I strongly advise others to stay away:

[b]Broken PvP system[/b]: Groups of T6 players hunt solos just for fun, not for loot or resources. It is neither competitive nor skill-based. Just organized bullying.

[b]Severe death penalties[/b]: After investing hours to reach T5 and build an ornithopter, I was instantly killed and lost everything. The grind to recover is exhausting and discouraging.

[b]No proper group support[/b]: Funcom claims players should group up, yet there is no group finder or matchmaking system. Solo players are left stranded and easy prey.

[b]Toxic community behavior[/b]: Many players in DD chat brag about killing others simply to stop their progress. The game seems to encourage griefing rather than fair competition.

[b]Unbalanced gameplay[/b]: There is no way for less experienced or solo players to stand a chance against geared, organized zergs.

A little more detail on those:
[list]
[*] Firstly, the game is set in the Dune universe. The Dune universe is amazing, so the game definately has that going for it.
[*] Secondly, in some ways, the developer was pretty ambitious, for an MMO. The game has a very interesting story, it sports modular construction nearly anywhere, it allows a nearly full open world with very few load screen transitions, it has vehicle building and customization, including flying vehicles, and it includes a very skill-based melee combat system.
[*] Unfortunately, these things are only ambitious for an MMO. If the game was a single player game, they would all be fairly standard.
[*] And I am not sure why it is an MMO. I guess so that you can be surrounded by the ruins of buildings built by people who joined the game then left. Besides that, there is no need for any interaction with other players.
[*] After several hundred hours, when you reach end-game the game randomly forces in a PvP element, which is very strange after playing the game PvE that entire time. I am sure some PvP fans are glad it is there, but most players obviously just felt it was unnecessary and didn't play it and left the game.
[*] All that aside, the fact that the game is online kills it. Their servers are the worst I have ever seen in a AAA game. The server literally lags out, fully link-dead, every 20 mins or so, before recovering. It is genuinely an unacceptable issue, especially when deaths are so punishing.
[*] Things like a skill-based melee combat system are a good idea, but when the game lags out or just bugs out constantly, it is extremely frustrating.
[*] I am sure they will have another free weekend where the servers will be much better, but it is a bait and switch. If you pay for the game, when the weekend ends, they will go back to being garbage.
[*] Besides just needing a patch, the game would hugely benefit from being converted to single player and giving us the option of private servers to play with our friends or public servers for PvP lovers, like every other survival crafter out there.
[*] The next thing worth mentioning is the worm. This is the single worst mechanic I have ever seen in a game. I genuinely believe that the majority of players that left probably did it after a worm encounter. In a game with an insane amount of grinding (MMO mentality), if you get killed by the worm, you lose everything. Your loot, your gear, your vehicle, its insane and unnecessary. Also the game is buggy and laggy, as mentioned. So you can genuinely lose everything and it isn't even your fault. Very bad design decision.
[*] Last thing to mention is that you can't stop playing. The game is like a mobile game, if you take a single week off for real life stuff (family, friends, work), then they destroy your house and everything in it. I can't even fathom how dumb this decision was.
[/list]

Firstly, I have been playing this game for 1,000 hours. I have extensive gaming experience, and let me tell you, my opinion is that of a seasoned veteran.

Luring you in with the DUNE IP and promises not kept, only for it to grow worse with time as the creative direction and devs hack at it. AVOID AT ALL COSTS.

This game has gotten WORSE, not better, with every update. I am not talking about bugs, by the way. I am talking about game direction and design decisions made after release, which have turned this game into a bubble-wrapped farming simulator, devoid of players on even the most “populated” servers.

If you purchase the game, your experience will be: farm simulator > finally get to the deep desert > realize there are no people to fight or anything fun to do > realize it’s just a flight/farm simulator in the deep desert as well > get bored when you realize there is no endgame and leave, but be down the cost of the game.

Making a product worse after release deserves a fucking trophy for “crash and burn achievement” that honestly is almost awe-inspiring.

Now, for those of you pondering buying the game. My advice: DON’T. Stay away. You don’t need specifics.

But for those of you that need specifics to justify my review for whatever reason, very well — allow me to give you my justifications.

Firstly, when this game was released, after grinding for a bit in a PvE environment (which was unique and fun but tedious and boring after a while), you would eventually get to the deep desert, which was supposed to be an endgame of sorts for everyone, but mostly for PvP players. And the population of the game mostly consisted of these players. 

The deep desert consisted of amazingly fun ground-based melee and ranged PvP, as well as amazingly fun aerial combat and vehicle warfare. It was amazing.

Now there was no real endgame aside from content the players would make themselves. But there were incentives that would lure players to certain areas and the gameplay was amazingly fun. With some help this game would have had an amazing endgame.

But everything changed when the 3-stooges game designers attacked.

1) The game designers, in their infinite wisdom (or lack thereof), decided that in order to solve griefing, they would simply patch out of existence the viability of vehicle warfare — which hilariously did not solve griefing in any way, shape, or form. But it did essentially delete an enormously fun part of the game for a large portion of the player base. And well, those people who enjoyed ace-combat-style aerial PvP left. I personally saw entire guilds shrivel up and leave the game that were devoted to that content — some of which were people I played with. Genius game designers, patching their way through their game’s population.

But wait, there’s more.

2) In the current PvP balance meta, ranged dominates to an absurd degree. However, melee combat was still barely viable for PvP in the past. But the game designers, again in their infinite wisdom, decided they would nerf the single skill that made melee viable (IN A FUCKING DUNE GAME — A UNIVERSE WHERE GUNS ARE CONSIDERED OBSOLETE!). This resulted in almost the entire melee PvP community, as well as most people faithful to the Dune lore who wanted to engage in PvP, vanishing over the course of a few weeks. Again, I knew some of those players. More population lost... amazing.

There were several other changes made — small nails in the coffin — that caused the game to bleed players more and more:

3) Making the DD half-PvE. This watering down of the DD to cater to PvErs was not particularly bad. but increasing the flight time and the lack of danger of the DD robed that content of the thrill that it originally had. it also made it annoying having to fly for 5 minutes just to get to the place where you COULD find pvp. 

3) Making loot random so ground PvP players don’t have anything to fight over and no locations that would attract players into fights turning the DD into a flight simulator looking for players for pvp that became harder and harder to find until even the biggest servers such as harmony became ghost towns.

4) Patching a repair glitch. To give context: the game has massive durability-loss penalties for dying. This is a disincentive to engage in PvP (THEIR CONTENT! FFS). The community has asked for the removal of death-based durability loss SINCE FOREVER, but the game designers are apparently deaf. So when they patched a repair glitch, a huge portion of the game’s PvP community left because no one wants to grind for hard-to-replace gear just so they can enjoy the content they enjoy.
I think half the PvP community left because of this “fix.” Good job.
Its hilarious to think how much the population of the game would still exist if they just deleted death based durability loss. baffling really.

The game designers are much like stooges trying to solve issues but only making the game massively worse in the process, without even fixing the problems they tried to fix! haha. What makes this even more hilarious is that there have been perfectly good solutions given to the game designers, but those solutions have been ignored and in some cases deleted from their discord and reddit for embarrassing the game designers

They do not listen to their community as they destroy their game, while deleting posts on their Discord and Reddit that criticize their game direction and give perfect solutions to solve the game’s problems and get the population to return.

And when they do listen to their community, they only listen to their farming-simulator PvE community (which I suspect the game designers are largely part of) — just enough to destroy the endgame for everyone.

All the PvPers have left. All the PvErs that would support the PvPers have left.

All the PvErs that play for gear grind — the ones the developers dumbed the game down for so they could achieve the endgame loot without having to work for it — have now also left.

The fact that the very community the game designers catered to, at the expense of everyone else, has left the game is absolutely priceless.

All that remains are the few PvErs that enjoy their Dune-themed single-player creative Minecraft world. 

There is no content for anyone else.

The game designers have deleted it.

The main reason I keep returning to Conan Exiles, and why I won’t be coming back to this one anytime soon, is twofold:

1. Exiles lets you host a co-op server, which is perfect for tuning the difficulty for one or two players — exactly how I like to play games in this genre.

2. Because private servers exist, Exiles has a ton of fantastic mods. Mods keep games alive, and the decision not to support them for Awakening is, frankly, terrible.

I think the choice to block proper private servers and modding is driven by greed — anything that could potentially undercut the publisher’s bottom line is off the table. In my opinion, that’s why this game’s concurrent player count has fallen off a cliff, dropping to the same levels as the now-ancient Exiles barely five months after release.

Give players more freedom to enjoy your game and they’ll come back. But punish them for stepping away, or force them to pay for “private servers” with a fraction of the control games like this usually offer, and they simply won’t return.

After spending a good chunk of time in Dune: Awakening, I can say it’s a great game but I hate the endgame and how it constantly forces you to come back and if you don't, you lose everything. Exploration is hands-down one of the strongest parts of the game. Arrakis feels huge, harsh, but incredibly rewarding to learn. The world isn’t just big for the sake of being big; it’s dense with little pockets of lore, resources, and random encounters that make every trip out feel like an adventure. 

That said… like most survival/MMO hybrids, the grind exists. It’s not unbearable, but after a while you definitely feel that familiar loop of gathering → crafting → upgrading → repeat. I didn’t mind it most of the time, but it’s something players should know going in.

It’s also pretty depressing to watch a server slowly die off; after a few months, most people stop maintaining their bases, and whole areas become abandoned wastelands. It fits the theme of Arrakis, sure, but gameplay-wise it feels like a flaw.

Aside from that, though? The game is genuinely cool. The atmosphere, the tension, the freedom to explore, and the overall Dune vibe make it something special. If the devs tweak the long-term base upkeep system, I think it could go from “great” to “top tier.”

I made a pretty big dent in the game so far even at 13 hours. Right off, let's start with combat, which is a big deal here. First, melee could be better with the timing considering it is a MMO that is completely reliant on your connection to the servers. If there is any lag, you will often miss the extremely tight timing for parries. If you miss those, the souls level NPC difficulty will overwhelm. Like a lot of MMORPG games, You have to run back to your corpse to recover lost money and roughly half your inventory in materials. If you get killed by the worms, you lose everything with no corpse. Those last bits are fine to me as we need incentive to get better. The issue I've had is no matter how long I play, I cannot seem to master the melee combat, and the only way to fight shielded enemies at 13 hours in is the "slow blade" and mastering parries, dodges, and everything else that's highly dependent on timing in a system that should forgive you with a margin of error for lag spikes. This is also further exacerbated by a very short stamina bar. I suppose Funcom assumed we would be raiding PvE in larger groups, but as we all know, PvE is better done solo or with maybe one other friend.

With all of that out of the way, there is no real base insurance. You can copy your base layout, but any items locked in storage at the time of the copy/paste get deleted forever. So, if you had 20 days worth of battery life in the generators, guess what -- you're going farming again. You will have to repeat all of the grinding to rebuild your base despite them flat out telling you that it's a type of base insurance to copy/paste your base. Never mind the tax in Solari every week to the CHOAM. It's really a game for people who have friends. But, like many of us who are too old to care, don't typically have work friends that play games, or are just loners, I found the difficulty curve just a little on the harsh side. All of the senseless life simulation is basically just too much tedium for anyone who has a real life to be fair.

On PvP: I did not encounter anyone real players wishing me harm because I stayed out of the well marked zones for PvP. As far as I could tell, the second zone has a fair number of PvP zones, but nothing a solo player can't avoid. It might take you longer to find what you're looking for, but you can play it safe. Again though, you're faced with a lot of unnecessary tedium.

Over all, the game absolutely needs private servers where we can control difficulty curves and most importantly QoL features that are prevalent in nearly all survival games. The way they did private servers is a nightmare of money grubbing and laughable ego. You can check it out for yourself on Funcoom's website. Since I doubt very much they will change things for the better -- because looking at the developer's track record since Anarchy Online -- I would say stay well away from this game. Honestly, the Dune franchise could have done with a single player story mode with optional multiplayer combined with battlefield simulation rather than what Funcom is trying and failing to do well. In short, this game is annoying.

The desert takes, but it should also teach.

I came into Dune: Awakening as someone who loves both the books and the design of games. I wanted to see how a studio would turn Herbert’s world of discipline, scarcity, and survival into a living MMO. After playing, I think they built something that looks like Dune but does not think like Dune.

Water drains too fast, sunstroke comes in seconds, and the “Fremen Stillsuit” – named exactly that – recovers maybe a quarter of a bar when empty. Lore tells us this suit keeps 98 percent of body moisture through movement. In the game, it barely functions at all. It is not about difficulty; it is about coherence. When a system called a “Stillsuit” fails to still anything, the world stops making sense. Instead of feeling like a careful survivor, you feel like you are babysitting a broken meter.

During the alpha I asked why we could not walk the desert like the Fremen do. The answer was, “We tested it. It was boring.” But the Fremen never walked to be entertained – they walked to live. Without desert walking, there is no rhythm, no contrast between calm and danger. Thumpers arrive only mid-to-late game, used purely as distractions instead of deliberate calls to the Maker. Vehicles appear early instead – loud tracked tricycles that pound the sand and summon worms faster. Once a worm notices you, you cannot lose it. Speed is your only defense, and speed makes more noise. That is not game balance. That is the ecosystem of Arrakis turned upside down.

Everything works in isolation: hydration meters, worms, thumpers, vehicles. But nothing supports anything else. You can feel the effort – the art direction is gorgeous, storms look alive, flight feels good – but the systems do not share a common idea. They took the nouns of Dune (Stillsuit, Thumper, Shai-Hulud) and forgot the verbs that give them meaning (preserve, walk, respect). The result is a game that constantly breaks its own mythology. It punishes patience, rewards noise, and confuses endurance with annoyance.

Slow the cadence. Let the Stillsuit work. Make the desert something to learn, not something to escape. Give the worm back its mystery and the player a reason to tread lightly. Funcom clearly has the tools to fix this. Under the current systems is a game that could teach patience instead of reflex, humility instead of hurry.

Dune: Awakening is visually stunning and mechanically ambitious, but it misunderstands the lesson of its own world. The desert should not be loud. The desert should not be fast. The desert should not be easy. The desert should be sacred.

Until it remembers that, I cannot recommend it.
